page.title: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender characters

rev.comment: rm per character images in list article per [[WP:NFLISTS]].
rev.diff:
Line 17: Line 17:
===Aang===
===Aang===
{{Main|Aang}}
{{Main|Aang}}
â
[[Image:Aang1.png|130px|right|thumb|Avatar Aang]]
 
Aang ({{zh |s=å®æ |p=Än Ãng}}) is voiced by [[Mitchel Musso]] in the unaired pilot<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mitchel-musso.org/filmography.php|title=Mitchell Musso Filmography|publisher=Mitchel Musso Tribute|accessdate=March 15, 2009}}</ref> and [[Zach Tyler Eisen]]<ref name="VarietyReview1">{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117926289.html?categoryid=32&cs=1|title=Avatar: The Last Airbender Review|last=Fries|first=Laura|date=February 21, 2005|work=Variety TV|publisher=Reed-Elsevier Inc.|
Aang ({{zh |s=å®æ |p=Än Ãng}}) is voiced by [[Mitchel Musso]] in the unaired pilot<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mitchel-musso.org/filmography.php|title=Mitchell Musso Filmography|publisher=Mitchel Musso Tribute|accessdate=March 15, 2009}}</ref> and [[Zach Tyler Eisen]]<ref name="VarietyReview1">{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117926289.html?categoryid=32&cs=1|title=Avatar: The Last Airbender Review|last=Fries|first=Laura|date=February 21, 2005|work=Variety TV|publisher=Reed-Elsevier Inc.|
accessdate=May 30, 2008}}</ref> for the remainder of the animated series. He is portrayed by [[Noah Ringer]] in the live-action film.<ref name=more>{{cite news|title=More are cast in M. Night Shyamalan's Last Airbender|work=[[Sci Fi Wire]]|date= March 13, 2009|url=http://scifiwire.com/2009/03/more-are-cast-in-m-night.php|accessdate= March 13, 2009}}</ref> He is the primary [[protagonist]] of the series and current incarnation of the [[Universe of Avatar: The Last Airbender#Avatar|Avatar]], who is the spirit of the planet manifested in human form.<ref name="The Boy in the Iceberg">{{cite episode|title=The Boy in the Iceberg|airdate=February 21, 2005|season=1|number=1|credits=Director: Dave Filoni, Writers: Michael Dante DiMartino, Bryan Konietzko|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 1)#ep1}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Britt|first=Aaron|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/10/magazine/10wwln-guest-t.html?_r=2&scp=2&sq=avatar&st=cse&oref=login|title=On Language â Avatar â NYTimes.com|publisher=New York Times|date=August 8, 2008|accessdate=November 30, 2008}}</ref> A [[reluctant hero]], Aang often acts in a fun-loving, carefree manner.<ref name="The Warriors Of Kyoshi">{{cite episode|title=The Warriors of Kyoshi|airdate=March 4, 2005|season=1|number=4|credits=Director: Giancarlo Volpe; Writer: Nick Malis|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 1)#ep4}}</ref> His [[pacifism|pacifist]] and [[vegetarian]] nature demonstrates his love for life, a primary trait of [[Buddhism]]. The creators intended Aang to "defeat enemies with his wits" and be a "[[trickster]] hero".<ref name="IGN Interview-Solving Problems">{{cite interview|last=DiMartino|first=Michael Dante|last2=Konietzko|first2=Bryan|interviewer=Eduardo Vasconcellos|program=IGN Entertainment|title=Interview: Avatar's Bryan Konietzko and Michael Dante DiMartino|url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/818/818284p1.html|date=September 6, 2007|accessdate=November 11, 2007}}</ref><ref name="NickMagInterview2">{{cite journal|last=DiMartino|first=Michael Dante|author-link=Michael Dante DiMartino|coauthors=Konietzko, Bryan|title=Myth Conceptions|journal=Nickelodeon Magazine|page=7|year=2006|issue=Winter 2006}}</ref> Though Aang generally acts in a playful, carefree manner, he becomes more serious during crisis and danger.<ref name="The Desert">{{cite episode|title=The Desert|airdate=June 14, 2006|season=2|number=11|credits=Director: Lauren MacMullan; Writer: Tim Hedrick|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 2)#ep31}}</ref><ref name="Sozin's Comet, Part 3: Into the Inferno">{{cite episode|title=Sozin's Comet, Part 3: Into the Inferno|airdate=July 19, 2008|season=3|number=20|credits=Director: Joaquim dos Santos; Writer: Michael Dante DiMartino, Bryan Konietzko|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 3)#ep60}}</ref>
accessdate=May 30, 2008}}</ref> for the remainder of the animated series. He is portrayed by [[Noah Ringer]] in the live-action film.<ref name=more>{{cite news|title=More are cast in M. Night Shyamalan's Last Airbender|work=[[Sci Fi Wire]]|date= March 13, 2009|url=http://scifiwire.com/2009/03/more-are-cast-in-m-night.php|accessdate= March 13, 2009}}</ref> He is the primary [[protagonist]] of the series and current incarnation of the [[Universe of Avatar: The Last Airbender#Avatar|Avatar]], who is the spirit of the planet manifested in human form.<ref name="The Boy in the Iceberg">{{cite episode|title=The Boy in the Iceberg|airdate=February 21, 2005|season=1|number=1|credits=Director: Dave Filoni, Writers: Michael Dante DiMartino, Bryan Konietzko|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 1)#ep1}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Britt|first=Aaron|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/10/magazine/10wwln-guest-t.html?_r=2&scp=2&sq=avatar&st=cse&oref=login|title=On Language â Avatar â NYTimes.com|publisher=New York Times|date=August 8, 2008|accessdate=November 30, 2008}}</ref> A [[reluctant hero]], Aang often acts in a fun-loving, carefree manner.<ref name="The Warriors Of Kyoshi">{{cite episode|title=The Warriors of Kyoshi|airdate=March 4, 2005|season=1|number=4|credits=Director: Giancarlo Volpe; Writer: Nick Malis|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 1)#ep4}}</ref> His [[pacifism|pacifist]] and [[vegetarian]] nature demonstrates his love for life, a primary trait of [[Buddhism]]. The creators intended Aang to "defeat enemies with his wits" and be a "[[trickster]] hero".<ref name="IGN Interview-Solving Problems">{{cite interview|last=DiMartino|first=Michael Dante|last2=Konietzko|first2=Bryan|interviewer=Eduardo Vasconcellos|program=IGN Entertainment|title=Interview: Avatar's Bryan Konietzko and Michael Dante DiMartino|url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/818/818284p1.html|date=September 6, 2007|accessdate=November 11, 2007}}</ref><ref name="NickMagInterview2">{{cite journal|last=DiMartino|first=Michael Dante|author-link=Michael Dante DiMartino|coauthors=Konietzko, Bryan|title=Myth Conceptions|journal=Nickelodeon Magazine|page=7|year=2006|issue=Winter 2006}}</ref> Though Aang generally acts in a playful, carefree manner, he becomes more serious during crisis and danger.<ref name="The Desert">{{cite episode|title=The Desert|airdate=June 14, 2006|season=2|number=11|credits=Director: Lauren MacMullan; Writer: Tim Hedrick|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 2)#ep31}}</ref><ref name="Sozin's Comet, Part 3: Into the Inferno">{{cite episode|title=Sozin's Comet, Part 3: Into the Inferno|airdate=July 19, 2008|season=3|number=20|credits=Director: Joaquim dos Santos; Writer: Michael Dante DiMartino, Bryan Konietzko|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 3)#ep60}}</ref>
Line 25: Line 24:
===Katara===
===Katara===
{{Main|Katara (Avatar: The Last Airbender)}}
{{Main|Katara (Avatar: The Last Airbender)}}
â
[[Image:katara.png|130px|right|thumb|Katara performing Waterbending]]
 
Katara ({{zh |s=å¡å¡æ |p=KÇ TÇlÄ}}) is voiced by [[Mae Whitman]] in the animated series<ref name="VarietyReview1" /> and portrayed by [[Nicola Peltz]] in the live-action film.<ref name="more"/> She is the last remaining waterbender from the Southern Water Tribe, due to an invasion by the [[Universe of Avatar: The Last Airbender#Navy|Southern Raiders]] and kidnapping of all waterbenders in the tribe years previously.<ref name="The Avatar Returns">{{cite episode|title=The Avatar Returns|airdate=February 21, 2005|season=1|number=2|credits=Director: Dave Filoni; Writers: Michael Dante DiMartino, Bryan Konietzko|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 1)#ep2}}</ref> By the age of fourteen, she had mastered the art of waterbending,<ref name="NickMagScan04">{{cite journal|last=Pittarese|first=Frank|title=Nation Exploration|journal=Nickelodeon Magazine|page=2|year=2006|issue=Winter 2006}}</ref> and thus began teaching Aang waterbending alongside his study of earthbending.<ref name="Bitter Work"/> A "protective sister" and "Motherly" for the group,<ref name="IGNreviewep1">{{cite web|url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/845/845279p1.html|title="The Boy in the Iceberg" Review|publisher=IGN|author=Mell, Tory Ireland|date=January 14, 2008|accessdate=March 15, 2009}}</ref> Katara is very stubborn and is known for resisting gender stereotypes and discrimination.<ref name="The Waterbending Master"/> Despite this, she is shown to be very nurturing, acting as den mother for the group. She usually cooks their meals, washes their clothes, and takes responsibility for the group's actions.<ref name="Bitter Work"/> Katara is shown to be a very skilled waterbender who can cleanly cut through objects with watery whips. She also masters a difficult skill which involves the manipulation of liquids within a living creature (bloodbending).<ref name="The Puppetmaster">{{cite episode|title=The Puppetmaster|airdate=October 25, 2007|season=3|number=8|credits=Director: Joaquim dos Santos; Writer: Tim Hedrick|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 3)#ep48}}</ref>.
Katara ({{zh |s=å¡å¡æ |p=KÇ TÇlÄ}}) is voiced by [[Mae Whitman]] in the animated series<ref name="VarietyReview1" /> and portrayed by [[Nicola Peltz]] in the live-action film.<ref name="more"/> She is the last remaining waterbender from the Southern Water Tribe, due to an invasion by the [[Universe of Avatar: The Last Airbender#Navy|Southern Raiders]] and kidnapping of all waterbenders in the tribe years previously.<ref name="The Avatar Returns">{{cite episode|title=The Avatar Returns|airdate=February 21, 2005|season=1|number=2|credits=Director: Dave Filoni; Writers: Michael Dante DiMartino, Bryan Konietzko|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 1)#ep2}}</ref> By the age of fourteen, she had mastered the art of waterbending,<ref name="NickMagScan04">{{cite journal|last=Pittarese|first=Frank|title=Nation Exploration|journal=Nickelodeon Magazine|page=2|year=2006|issue=Winter 2006}}</ref> and thus began teaching Aang waterbending alongside his study of earthbending.<ref name="Bitter Work"/> A "protective sister" and "Motherly" for the group,<ref name="IGNreviewep1">{{cite web|url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/845/845279p1.html|title="The Boy in the Iceberg" Review|publisher=IGN|author=Mell, Tory Ireland|date=January 14, 2008|accessdate=March 15, 2009}}</ref> Katara is very stubborn and is known for resisting gender stereotypes and discrimination.<ref name="The Waterbending Master"/> Despite this, she is shown to be very nurturing, acting as den mother for the group. She usually cooks their meals, washes their clothes, and takes responsibility for the group's actions.<ref name="Bitter Work"/> Katara is shown to be a very skilled waterbender who can cleanly cut through objects with watery whips. She also masters a difficult skill which involves the manipulation of liquids within a living creature (bloodbending).<ref name="The Puppetmaster">{{cite episode|title=The Puppetmaster|airdate=October 25, 2007|season=3|number=8|credits=Director: Joaquim dos Santos; Writer: Tim Hedrick|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 3)#ep48}}</ref>.
===Sokka===
===Sokka===
{{Main|Sokka}}
{{Main|Sokka}}
â
[[Image:Sokka the Thinker.png|thumb|right|130px|Sokka and his trusty [[boomerang]].]]
 
Sokka ({{zh |s=ç´¢å¡ |p=SÇo KÇ}}) is voiced by [[Jack DeSena]]<ref name="VarietyReview1" /> in the animated series and portrayed by [[Jackson Rathbone]] in the live-action film.<ref name="more"/> He is a 15-year-old warrior from the Southern Water Tribe, and Katara's brother, who describes himself as "sarcastic" "the smart one" and "meat-eating".<ref name="Bitter Work">{{cite episode|title=Bitter Work|airdate=June 2, 2006|season=2|number=9|credits=Director: Ethan Spaulding; Writer: Aaron Ehasz|series: Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 2)#ep29}}</ref> After rescuing Aang from the iceberg and discovering that he is the Avatar, he accompanies Aang on his quest to master the four elements and defeat the Fire Lord, ending the war and bringing peace to the world. Although he hails from a tribe of people with the ability to bend water, he was not given the gift and instead strives to become a worthy warrior and leader.<ref name="The Library">{{cite episode|title=The Library|airdate=June 14, 2006|season=2|number=10|credits=Director: Giancarlo Volpe; Writer: John O'Bryan|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 2)#ep30}}</ref> Instead of bending, he is frequently given opportunities to use his ingenuity and weapons, including his boomerang, machete, and a sword he forged from a meteorite.<ref name="Sokkas Master">{{cite episode|title=Sokka's Master|airdate=October 12, 2007|season=3|number=4|credits=Director: Giancarlo Volpe; Writer: Tim Hedrick|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 3)#ep44}}</ref>
Sokka ({{zh |s=ç´¢å¡ |p=SÇo KÇ}}) is voiced by [[Jack DeSena]]<ref name="VarietyReview1" /> in the animated series and portrayed by [[Jackson Rathbone]] in the live-action film.<ref name="more"/> He is a 15-year-old warrior from the Southern Water Tribe, and Katara's brother, who describes himself as "sarcastic" "the smart one" and "meat-eating".<ref name="Bitter Work">{{cite episode|title=Bitter Work|airdate=June 2, 2006|season=2|number=9|credits=Director: Ethan Spaulding; Writer: Aaron Ehasz|series: Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 2)#ep29}}</ref> After rescuing Aang from the iceberg and discovering that he is the Avatar, he accompanies Aang on his quest to master the four elements and defeat the Fire Lord, ending the war and bringing peace to the world. Although he hails from a tribe of people with the ability to bend water, he was not given the gift and instead strives to become a worthy warrior and leader.<ref name="The Library">{{cite episode|title=The Library|airdate=June 14, 2006|season=2|number=10|credits=Director: Giancarlo Volpe; Writer: John O'Bryan|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 2)#ep30}}</ref> Instead of bending, he is frequently given opportunities to use his ingenuity and weapons, including his boomerang, machete, and a sword he forged from a meteorite.<ref name="Sokkas Master">{{cite episode|title=Sokka's Master|airdate=October 12, 2007|season=3|number=4|credits=Director: Giancarlo Volpe; Writer: Tim Hedrick|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 3)#ep44}}</ref>
Line 37: Line 34:
===Toph===
===Toph===
{{Main|Toph Bei Fong}}
{{Main|Toph Bei Fong}}
â
[[Image:Toph ep26.png|right|thumb|130px|Toph in Earthbending pose.]]
 
Toph ({{zh |s=åæ¹æè |p=BÄifÄng TuÃ²fÃº}}) is voiced by [[Jessie Flower]]<ref name="TV Guide Cast">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/avatar-airbender/cast/194673|title=Avatar: The Last Airbender Cast and Details|publisher=[[TV Guide]]|date=|accessdate=November 26, 2008}}</ref> in the animated series. She is a blind [[Earthbender|Earthbending]] grandmaster of the prestigious Bei Fong family in the Earth Kingdom.<ref name="The Blind Bandit"/> Her parents are overprotective and view her blindness as a disability. Though blind, Toph has the unique ability to use Earthbending to "feel" even the most minute vibrations in the earth, be it the presence of trees and buildings or the march of ants several meters away. Through this heightened seismic sense, she can visualize where people are, their relative distance to her, and their physical build. This sense provides her with a distinct advantage when facing other Earthbenders in combat, as they characteristically require contact with the ground and extract rocks from their surroundings.<ref name="The Blind Bandit" /> As another result of her blindness, Toph has acquired an acute sense of hearing, enabling her to recognize people by the sound of their voices and to home in on distant conversations.<ref name="The Desert">{{cite episode|title=The Desert|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 2)#ep31|season=2|number=11|transcripturl=http://www.avatarspiritmedia.net/transcripts.php?ep=211|credits=Director: Lauren MacMullan; Writer: Tim Hedrick|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon}}</ref> Unlike other Earthbenders, Toph has a distinct style of earthbending produced by her blindness that is not based on [[Hung Gar]] as is conventional, but rather the [[Southern Praying Mantis (martial art)|Southern Praying Mantis]]. This style places emphasis on short power (quick generation of energy) and low kicks that complement Toph's build. Also Toph is able to sense when someone is lying to her or her friends.<ref>{{cite web| author = Lee, Henry and Harry A. White| title = Secrets of Southern Praying Mantis â Henry Poo Yee's story| publisher = Kung Fu Magazine| url = http://ezine.kungfumagazine.com/magazine/article.php?article=178| date = March 17, 1992| accessdate = March 17, 2009}}</ref>
Toph ({{zh |s=åæ¹æè |p=BÄifÄng TuÃ²fÃº}}) is voiced by [[Jessie Flower]]<ref name="TV Guide Cast">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/avatar-airbender/cast/194673|title=Avatar: The Last Airbender Cast and Details|publisher=[[TV Guide]]|date=|accessdate=November 26, 2008}}</ref> in the animated series. She is a blind [[Earthbender|Earthbending]] grandmaster of the prestigious Bei Fong family in the Earth Kingdom.<ref name="The Blind Bandit"/> Her parents are overprotective and view her blindness as a disability. Though blind, Toph has the unique ability to use Earthbending to "feel" even the most minute vibrations in the earth, be it the presence of trees and buildings or the march of ants several meters away. Through this heightened seismic sense, she can visualize where people are, their relative distance to her, and their physical build. This sense provides her with a distinct advantage when facing other Earthbenders in combat, as they characteristically require contact with the ground and extract rocks from their surroundings.<ref name="The Blind Bandit" /> As another result of her blindness, Toph has acquired an acute sense of hearing, enabling her to recognize people by the sound of their voices and to home in on distant conversations.<ref name="The Desert">{{cite episode|title=The Desert|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 2)#ep31|season=2|number=11|transcripturl=http://www.avatarspiritmedia.net/transcripts.php?ep=211|credits=Director: Lauren MacMullan; Writer: Tim Hedrick|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon}}</ref> Unlike other Earthbenders, Toph has a distinct style of earthbending produced by her blindness that is not based on [[Hung Gar]] as is conventional, but rather the [[Southern Praying Mantis (martial art)|Southern Praying Mantis]]. This style places emphasis on short power (quick generation of energy) and low kicks that complement Toph's build. Also Toph is able to sense when someone is lying to her or her friends.<ref>{{cite web| author = Lee, Henry and Harry A. White| title = Secrets of Southern Praying Mantis â Henry Poo Yee's story| publisher = Kung Fu Magazine| url = http://ezine.kungfumagazine.com/magazine/article.php?article=178| date = March 17, 1992| accessdate = March 17, 2009}}</ref>
Line 44: Line 40:
===Zuko===
===Zuko===
{{Main|Zuko}}
{{Main|Zuko}}
â
[[File:Zuko and Iroh.jpg|thumb|right|Zuko (left) and [[List of Avatar: The Last Airbender characters#Iroh|Iroh]] (right) were initially depicted as the main [[antagonist]]s but their role in the show gradually evolved as the series progressed.]]
 
Prince Zuko ({{zh |s=èç§ |p=SÅ« KÄ}}) is voiced by [[Dante Basco]]<ref name="VarietyReview1" /> in the animated series and portrayed by [[Dev Patel]] in the live-action film.<ref name="more"/> At first, Zuko starts the show out with a shaved head except for a ponytail, but as the series continues he first shaves his head and then grows it back. He was originally the primary [[antagonist]] of the series, but developed into an [[anti-hero]], and later a [[protagonist]]. Zuko had been exiled prior to the beginning of the series by his father,<ref name="Zuko Alone">{{cite episode|title=Zuko Alone|airdate=May 12, 2006|season=2|number=7|credits=Director: Lauren MacMullan; Writer: Elizabeth Welch Ehasz|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 2)#ep27}}</ref> and believed that capturing the Avatar was the only way to regain his honor.<ref name="The Boy In The Iceberg">{{cite episode|title=The Boy in the Iceberg|airdate=February 21, 2005|season=1|number=1|credits=Director: Dave Filoni; Writers: Michael Dante DiMartino, Bryan Konietzko|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 1)#ep1}}</ref> Zuko's ancestry reflects his own conflicted nature; his paternal great-grandfather is Fire Lord Sozin, the one who started the war, while his maternal great-grandfather is Avatar Roku.<ref name="The Avatar And The Firelord">{{cite episode|title=The Avatar and the Firelord|airdate=October 24, 2007|season=3|number=6|credits=Director: Ethan Spaulding; Writer: Elizabeth Welch Ehasz|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 3)#ep46}}</ref>
Prince Zuko ({{zh |s=èç§ |p=SÅ« KÄ}}) is voiced by [[Dante Basco]]<ref name="VarietyReview1" /> in the animated series and portrayed by [[Dev Patel]] in the live-action film.<ref name="more"/> At first, Zuko starts the show out with a shaved head except for a ponytail, but as the series continues he first shaves his head and then grows it back. He was originally the primary [[antagonist]] of the series, but developed into an [[anti-hero]], and later a [[protagonist]]. Zuko had been exiled prior to the beginning of the series by his father,<ref name="Zuko Alone">{{cite episode|title=Zuko Alone|airdate=May 12, 2006|season=2|number=7|credits=Director: Lauren MacMullan; Writer: Elizabeth Welch Ehasz|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 2)#ep27}}</ref> and believed that capturing the Avatar was the only way to regain his honor.<ref name="The Boy In The Iceberg">{{cite episode|title=The Boy in the Iceberg|airdate=February 21, 2005|season=1|number=1|credits=Director: Dave Filoni; Writers: Michael Dante DiMartino, Bryan Konietzko|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 1)#ep1}}</ref> Zuko's ancestry reflects his own conflicted nature; his paternal great-grandfather is Fire Lord Sozin, the one who started the war, while his maternal great-grandfather is Avatar Roku.<ref name="The Avatar And The Firelord">{{cite episode|title=The Avatar and the Firelord|airdate=October 24, 2007|season=3|number=6|credits=Director: Ethan Spaulding; Writer: Elizabeth Welch Ehasz|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 3)#ep46}}</ref>
Line 51: Line 46:
===Iroh===
===Iroh===
{{Main|Iroh}}
{{Main|Iroh}}
â
[[Image:IrohWhiteLotus.png|right|thumb|Iroh leading the 'Order of the White Lotus']]
 
Iroh ({{zh |s=è¾æ´ |p=AÃ¬ LÃ¹o}}) is voiced by [[Mako (actor)|Mako]] for two seasons<ref name="VarietyReview1"/> and [[Greg Baldwin]] for the final season<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dvd.ign.com/articles/849/849365p1.html|title=Avatar: The Last Airbender - Book 3: Fire / Volume 2 Review:|author=Harris, Jeffery| accessdate=March 17, 2009|publisher=IGN|date=February 4, 2008}}</ref> of the animated series. He is portrayed by [[Shaun Toub]] in the live-action film.<ref name="more"/> Commonly known as the "Dragon of the West", Iroh is a Firebending master and former heir to the Fire Nation throne. After the death of his son during the Siege of Ba Sing Se, and Iroh returns to the Fire Nation in mourning, his younger brother Ozai was named Fire Lord.<ref name="Zuko Alone"/> Iroh, unlike most firebenders, is shown to be very perceptive of and in tune with all four elements, instead of just fire. Iroh utilizes this to great effect as he is one of the few people who learned how to redirect lightning.<ref name="Bitter Work"/> He is also very well-versed in the history of firebending methods and generates his fire and lightning not from corrupted fury, as is conventional in the modern-era, but from wisdom given to him by dragons, the original source of firebending.<ref name="The Firebending Masters"/> As a member of the Order of the White Lotus, Iroh has many connections throughout the Four Nations, and he organized an assault on Fire Nation-controlled Ba Sing Se which turned the city back to Earth Kingdom rule.<ref name="Sozin's Comet, Part 3: Into the Inferno"/><ref name="Sozin's Comet, Part 4: Avatar Aang"/>
Iroh ({{zh |s=è¾æ´ |p=AÃ¬ LÃ¹o}}) is voiced by [[Mako (actor)|Mako]] for two seasons<ref name="VarietyReview1"/> and [[Greg Baldwin]] for the final season<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dvd.ign.com/articles/849/849365p1.html|title=Avatar: The Last Airbender - Book 3: Fire / Volume 2 Review:|author=Harris, Jeffery| accessdate=March 17, 2009|publisher=IGN|date=February 4, 2008}}</ref> of the animated series. He is portrayed by [[Shaun Toub]] in the live-action film.<ref name="more"/> Commonly known as the "Dragon of the West", Iroh is a Firebending master and former heir to the Fire Nation throne. After the death of his son during the Siege of Ba Sing Se, and Iroh returns to the Fire Nation in mourning, his younger brother Ozai was named Fire Lord.<ref name="Zuko Alone"/> Iroh, unlike most firebenders, is shown to be very perceptive of and in tune with all four elements, instead of just fire. Iroh utilizes this to great effect as he is one of the few people who learned how to redirect lightning.<ref name="Bitter Work"/> He is also very well-versed in the history of firebending methods and generates his fire and lightning not from corrupted fury, as is conventional in the modern-era, but from wisdom given to him by dragons, the original source of firebending.<ref name="The Firebending Masters"/> As a member of the Order of the White Lotus, Iroh has many connections throughout the Four Nations, and he organized an assault on Fire Nation-controlled Ba Sing Se which turned the city back to Earth Kingdom rule.<ref name="Sozin's Comet, Part 3: Into the Inferno"/><ref name="Sozin's Comet, Part 4: Avatar Aang"/>
Line 59: Line 53:
===Azula===
===Azula===
{{Main|Azula}}
{{Main|Azula}}
â
[[Image:AzulaHiRes.png|130px|right|thumb|Azula can see through people's weaknesses.]]
 
[[Princess]] Azula ({{zh |s=é¿ç¥æ |p=Ã ZÃ¹lÄ}}) is voiced by [[Grey DeLisle]] in the animated series and played by [[Summer Bishil]] in the movie. Though making cameo appearances in the first season of the series, Azula became the primary antagonist in the second season.<ref name="The Avatar State">{{cite episode|title=The Avatar State|airdate=March 17, 2006|season=2|number=1|credits=Director: Giancarlo Volpe; Writers: Aaron Ehasz, Elizabeth Welch Ehasz, Tim Hedrick, John O'Bryan|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 2)#ep21}}</ref> She is a gifted [[Avatar:_The_Last_Airbender#Elements|Firebending]] master, able to bend blue fire and lightning, and is more highly favored than her brother. After Admiral Zhao's death, Azula is sent out to not only stop Aang at all costs, but also to capture and humiliate her brother. She believes that power and domination are what makes a person strong.<ref name="The Crossroads of Destiny" /> She lacks empathy, treats people as expendable, and is unable to view them as her equals. Her [[amorality]] and ability to act without hesitation or remorse also accounts for her ability to create [[lightning]], as the skill requires peace of mind.<ref name="Bitter Work"/> Despite her cruel temperament, she is shown to harbor insecurities and is driven to madness when her friends, Mai and Ty Lee, betray her.<ref name="The Boiling Rock2">{{cite episode|title=The Boiling Rock, Part 2|airdate=July 16, 2008|season=3|number=15|credits=Director: Ethan Spaulding; Writer: Joshua Hamilton|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 3)#ep55}}</ref>
[[Princess]] Azula ({{zh |s=é¿ç¥æ |p=Ã ZÃ¹lÄ}}) is voiced by [[Grey DeLisle]] in the animated series and played by [[Summer Bishil]] in the movie. Though making cameo appearances in the first season of the series, Azula became the primary antagonist in the second season.<ref name="The Avatar State">{{cite episode|title=The Avatar State|airdate=March 17, 2006|season=2|number=1|credits=Director: Giancarlo Volpe; Writers: Aaron Ehasz, Elizabeth Welch Ehasz, Tim Hedrick, John O'Bryan|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 2)#ep21}}</ref> She is a gifted [[Avatar:_The_Last_Airbender#Elements|Firebending]] master, able to bend blue fire and lightning, and is more highly favored than her brother. After Admiral Zhao's death, Azula is sent out to not only stop Aang at all costs, but also to capture and humiliate her brother. She believes that power and domination are what makes a person strong.<ref name="The Crossroads of Destiny" /> She lacks empathy, treats people as expendable, and is unable to view them as her equals. Her [[amorality]] and ability to act without hesitation or remorse also accounts for her ability to create [[lightning]], as the skill requires peace of mind.<ref name="Bitter Work"/> Despite her cruel temperament, she is shown to harbor insecurities and is driven to madness when her friends, Mai and Ty Lee, betray her.<ref name="The Boiling Rock2">{{cite episode|title=The Boiling Rock, Part 2|airdate=July 16, 2008|season=3|number=15|credits=Director: Ethan Spaulding; Writer: Joshua Hamilton|series=Avatar: The Last Airbender|serieslink=Avatar: The Last Airbender|network=Nickelodeon|episodelink=Avatar: The Last Airbender (Season 3)#ep55}}</ref>
==Major recurring characters==
==Major recurring characters==
â
[[Image:Appa02.png|100px|thumb|right|Appa]]
 
* '''[[Appa]]''' ([[Dee Bradley Baker]] in both the animated series and the live-action film)<ref name="more"/><ref name="TV Guide Cast" /> is Aang's flying [[bison]] who serves as the group's main [[Mode of transport|form of transportation]] around the world. He is stuck in suspended animation with Aang for 100 years, and shares a very strong bond with him.<ref name="The Storm"/> He possesses the ability to fly and can use his tail to create powerful gusts of air. According to Aang, flying bison were the first Airbenders.<ref name="The Southern Air Temple"/>
* '''[[Appa]]''' ([[Dee Bradley Baker]] in both the animated series and the live-action film)<ref name="more"/><ref name="TV Guide Cast" /> is Aang's flying [[bison]] who serves as the group's main [[Mode of transport|form of transportation]] around the world. He is stuck in suspended animation with Aang for 100 years, and shares a very strong bond with him.<ref name="The Storm"/> He possesses the ability to fly and can use his tail to create powerful gusts of air. According to Aang, flying bison were the first Airbenders.<ref name="The Southern Air Temple"/>
*'''Suki''' ([[Jennie Kwan]] in the animated series,<ref name="TV Guide Cast" /> )<ref name="more"/> is the leader of the young female warriors of the Kyoshi Warriors.<ref name="The Warriors Of Kyoshi"/> She is an exceptionally skilled fighter and staunch ally of the protagonists. She was imprisoned by the Fire Nation after the Kyoshi Warriors were defeated by Azula, but was ultimately released by Sokka, Zuko, Hakoda, and Chit-Sang.<ref name="The Boiling Rock2"/> She remained with the protagonists thereafter and fought with Toph and Sokka to disable the Fire Nation air force. She is one of Sokka's love interests.
*'''Suki''' ([[Jennie Kwan]] in the animated series,<ref name="TV Guide Cast" /> )<ref name="more"/> is the leader of the young female warriors of the Kyoshi Warriors.<ref name="The Warriors Of Kyoshi"/> She is an exceptionally skilled fighter and staunch ally of the protagonists. She was imprisoned by the Fire Nation after the Kyoshi Warriors were defeated by Azula, but was ultimately released by Sokka, Zuko, Hakoda, and Chit-Sang.<ref name="The Boiling Rock2"/> She remained with the protagonists thereafter and fought with Toph and Sokka to disable the Fire Nation air force. She is one of Sokka's love interests.
â
[[File:Ozai.png|100px|right|thumb|Ozai]]
+
* '''[[Ozai (Avatar: The Last Airbender)|Fire Lord Ozai]]''' ([[Mark Hamill]] in the animated series,<ref name="TV Guide Cast" /> [[Cliff Curtis]] in the live-action film)<ref name="more"/> is the father of [[Zuko]] and [[Azula]], younger brother of [[Iroh]], and the main antagonist of the series. Although serving as the primary antagonist for the series, he primarily played a behind-the-scenes role during the first two seasons. His face was not shown until the first episode of Book 3. He is an extremely powerful firebender â one able to hold his own even against an Avatar fighting with its previous incarnation's skills. In ''[[Sozin's Comet: The Final Battle]]'', he renames himself the Phoenix King, ruler of the world, and appoints Azula to watch over the Fire Nation.<ref name="Sozin's Comet, Part 4: Avatar Aang"/> Due to his corruption and war mongering, Aang strips him of his firebending abilities and removes him from power.<ref name="Sozin's Comet, Part 4: Avatar Aang"/>
* '''[[Ozai (Avatar: The Last Airbender)|Fire Lord Ozai]]''' ([[Mark Hamill]] in the animated series,<ref name="TV Guide Cast" /> [[Cliff Curtis]] in the live-action film)<ref name="more"/> is the father of [[Zuko]] and [[Azula]], younger brother of [[Iroh]], and the main antagonist of the series. Although serving as the primary antagonist for the series, he primarily played a behind-the-scenes role during the first two seasons. His face was not shown until the first episode of Book 3. He is an extremely powerful firebender â one able to hold his own even against an Avatar fighting with its previous incarnation's skills. In ''[[Sozin's Comet: The Final Battle]]'', he renames himself the Phoenix King, ruler of the world, and appoints Azula to watch over the Fire Nation.<ref name="Sozin's Comet, Part 4: Avatar Aang"/> Due to his corruption and war mongering, Aang strips him of his firebending abilities and removes him from power.<ref name="Sozin's Comet, Part 4: Avatar Aang"/>
Line 75: Line 67:
* '''Mai''' ([[Cricket Leigh]] in the animated series)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywood.com/celebrity/Cricket_Leigh/3672334|title=Cricket Leigh | Biography, Photos, Movies, TV, Credits|publisher=Hollywood.com|date=November 21, 2008|accessdate=May 4, 2009}}</ref> is an impassive, bored, nearly emotionless young woman who, along with Ty Lee, at first accompanied Azula on her quest to capture Zuko, Iroh, and the Avatar.<ref name="The Avatar State"/> She has a very dry and cynical personality and sense of humor. She is a master of stealth and light weaponry; her primary weapons are [[FÅ«ma shuriken|shuriken daggers]], which she uses with great precision and which are kept concealed in her clothing.<ref name="Return To Omashu"/> Ultimately, her conscience chose Zuko over Azula and betrayed the latter, which lead to her imprisonment. She is released after Zuko defeats Azula.<ref name="Sozin's Comet, Part 4: Avatar Aang"/> She is Zuko's on and off girlfriend throughout Book 3.
* '''Mai''' ([[Cricket Leigh]] in the animated series)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywood.com/celebrity/Cricket_Leigh/3672334|title=Cricket Leigh | Biography, Photos, Movies, TV, Credits|publisher=Hollywood.com|date=November 21, 2008|accessdate=May 4, 2009}}</ref> is an impassive, bored, nearly emotionless young woman who, along with Ty Lee, at first accompanied Azula on her quest to capture Zuko, Iroh, and the Avatar.<ref name="The Avatar State"/> She has a very dry and cynical personality and sense of humor. She is a master of stealth and light weaponry; her primary weapons are [[FÅ«ma shuriken|shuriken daggers]], which she uses with great precision and which are kept concealed in her clothing.<ref name="Return To Omashu"/> Ultimately, her conscience chose Zuko over Azula and betrayed the latter, which lead to her imprisonment. She is released after Zuko defeats Azula.<ref name="Sozin's Comet, Part 4: Avatar Aang"/> She is Zuko's on and off girlfriend throughout Book 3.

* '''[[Momo (Avatar: The Last Airbender)|Momo]]''' ([[Dee Bradley Baker]] in both the animated series and the live-action film)<ref name="more"/> is an intelligent and curious winged [[lemur]]. Aang found him at the Southern Air Temple soon after starting his quest and decided to keep him as a pet.<ref name="The Southern Air Temple"/> He often picks fights with other winged and smaller creatures and with Appa over food.
